importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Santos surrendered to authorities on this date, beginning his 87-month prison sentence for fraud charges.
President Trump commuted Santos' sentence on this date, leading to his release from prison.
Santos was expelled from Congress on this date, marking a major political scandal involving fraud and biographical falsification.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Santos committed fraud during his 2022 congressional campaign, which led to criminal charges and subsequent expulsion from Congress.

keyTakeAways: Former Representative George Santos was released from prison after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence.
Santos pleaded guilty in 2024 to aggravated identity theft and wire fraud related to falsified personal information during his 2022 campaign.
Santos was expelled from Congress in December 2023, becoming only the sixth lawmaker ever to be expelled from the U.S. House.
Santos admitted to fabricating parts of his biography, including employment and educational history.
Trump commuted the sentence after Santos wrote an open letter pleading for fairness and acknowledging responsibility for his actions.

The commutation drew mixed reactions: supporters including Marjorie Taylor Greene praised the move, while House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries criticized Trump for prioritizing Santos over pressing national issues like healthcare.
Santos was serving his sentence at the Federal Correctional Institution in Fairton, New Jersey, and had been in solitary confinement for prolonged periods.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former U.S. Representative George Santos, convicted of aggravated identity theft and wire fraud for fabricating parts of his biography during his 2022 congressional campaign, was released from prison on October 18, 2025, after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence. Santos, who had been expelled from Congress in December 2023, had been serving his sentence at the Federal Correctional Institution in Fairton, New Jersey, and had spent significant time in solitary confinement. In a public letter, Santos pleaded for fairness and acknowledged responsibility for his actions. The commutation drew praise from political allies like Marjorie Taylor Greene, Lauren Boebert, and Matt Gaetz, who supported him throughout. However, it also drew criticism from House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, who argued that Trump should have addressed the healthcare crisis during the government shutdown instead. The case highlights tensions between executive clemency, political loyalty, and the accountability of public officials.
title: Former Rep. George Santos Released from Prison After Trump Commutes Sentence
